author: joeyaiello
body:
This is strongly tied to #716, but we want to make sure these have independent work items. 

Steps to reproduce
------------------
1. Open PowerShell on Linux/macOS
2. Hit Ctrl+Z

Expected behavior
-----------------
Current running process is forked to bg

Actual behavior
---------------
PowerShell itself is forked to bg and the user is bounced back out to bash (or whatever is the default shell that handled Ctrl+Z)

comments.author: lypanov

comments.body:
I look forward to a fix - this is a highly useful linux feature.

Is there a workaround or setting in powershell that would make it catch the ctrl-z rather than pass it back to bash?

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: @arvidcarlandercompose you might try adding a PSRL key handler: `Set-PSReadLineKeyHandler -Chord Ctrl+Z -ScriptBlock { <# some action #> }`

comments.body: You can use also [PsSuspend](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/pssuspend) and put it into your PATH, or use [Process Explorer](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/sysinternals/downloads/process-explorer), which as a GUI to suspend/resume processes.

comments.author: JordanShurmer
comments.body:
This feature would be really great to have.

In bash I frequently use this while developing.. I'd start a server and watch the logs at first, then when I want to do other things I'd simply hit Ctrl-Z and then use `bg` to keep it running in the background

In Bash: `^z` to suspend the current job. `fg` to resume it, `bg` to resume it in the background.

Here's the docs about [Job Control in GNU Bash](https://www.gnu.org/savannah-checkouts/gnu/bash/manual/bash.html) for all the details.


EDIT: fixed my "In Bash" summary and 'running in background' language
